bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1946

div1.p: Kean relates the history of the Kissinger family in their desire to obtain money and how Peabody organized the Kissinger Relief Fund. Kean goes on to say that there was an error in a pamphlet published by Peabody in the amount of pension money to be given to the Kissinger family.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1946
div1.opener:
AC
K
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
August 22 1946
My dear Colonel Henrch
div1.p:
Your letter of aug. 19th '46
has just come. It tells me of your letter
from Mrs Kissinger, and I am distressed
that you should be worried by her.
The case of the Kissingers was very wide-
ly publicized in the 1820s largely
through the efforts of Mr. James Edward
Peabody, who was connected with the
Public School system of New York City.
He was a very earnest, ardent and per-
haps uncritical publicist and did
much to get public recognition for
the volunteers for Camp Lazear experiments
and for all others connected actively with
Reed's work. I had a large accumulation
2-
of the micrographic and printed material, that he put
out but it has been gradually disposed
of in one way or another. The Kissingers
were his hobby and he organized the
Kissinger Releif fund which bought
them a house, a cow, 2 1/2 1/2 acres of land
and other material help accounting to
$8,200.00. When Kissinger's original
pension of $12 a month was raised to
$10000 a month, he rather by an error of
the Pension Bureau they gave him both
pensions for a member of years and
then (rather meanly I thought) called
on Kissinger to refund $1699.60 paid
him by their negligence. Of course he
could not do it, and his friends
got him excused by a special act.
The Kissingers have been the most
successful beggars connected with the
Reed Yellow Fever Episode and you may
AC
K
3
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
be sure that she will get every thing
that the law allows in the way of
funeral expenses for him and a pension
for herself - as a veteran's widow.
The government in generous in these
matters, and all she has to do is
to apply to the Veteran's Administra-
tion in Washington, or to her Congressman
if she prefers a political channel, to
get it. I have no doubt that she has
already appealed to Mr. Peabody.
I have not heard of any appeals from
the widows of other beneficiaries of the Act
of Feb. 23, 1929 conferring the medals and pen-
sions, such as Mrs Kissinger is making.
Of course she has no claim to have Kissingers
pension continued to her. There is an allow-
ance for funeral expenses for veterans.
Do not bother your head about these matters.
4
You will find they have all been seen
to by the local Veterans organizations.
As to his illnesses having been caused by
his experimental yellow fever attack, you
and I know that such sequelae do not
occur many years later as a result of yellow
fever. The doctor who cured his paraplegia
with medicine quite promptly, evidently
knew the diagnosis.

Siler phoned me yesterday that he would
write to you that the date of meeting of the
Walter Reed Memorial Assn has been
set to make it possible for you to attend
it. It is a simple affair of 8 or 10 member
(there are 14 in all), like a Directors meeting
as it is, and we are much pleased at
you going to so much trouble and expense
to attend it. I will inclose a memo sheet
which I have found in my papers which
has reference to a pamphlet which Peabody
published as I think for the use of the
P.S. Hench
AC
K
5
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
Public Schools or some such purpose.
I have the galley proof of it in 7 galleys
which I will send to you if you wish it.
It states inter alia that I had recommended
and Ireland and other high officials had
approved in 1926 “a pension of 3000 dollars a year for
each of the three widows and for the Kissin-
gers”. This is certainly an error. My
recommendation was made to the Senate
Pension Committee in Jan. or Feb. 1903 that
approximately Reed's base pay be
continued to his widow. This was less
than 3 months after Reed's death. I cer-
tainly never dreamed of recomming such
a pension to Kissinger. It may be that
this galley may have been for publication
in a magazine, but I am quite sure it was
Peabody's, tho no name is signed to it.
6
If she writes to me I will tell her that
she is entitled to a pension as a widow
of a Spanish War veteran and no other pension
and that the Veterans Administration can
inform her as to funeral expenses.
